As to the question whether a developmental - psychological examination would be harmful to NORP ’s health and well - being , L .- W. also referred to the therapist treating NORP

CARDINAL . At the final hearing before ORG on DATE , counsel for the applicant repeated the request to call NORP as a witness , given that in view of the conclusions reached in the developmental - psychological examination it did not appear that a new interview would be harmful to NORP ’s health and well - being . Counsel further argued that not hearing NORP constituted a breach of LAW ( d ) of the LAW in that the defence had not been afforded the opportunity to put questions to NORP whereas a conviction of the applicant would solely or to a decisive degree be based on NORP ’s statement . CARDINAL . On DATE ORG delivered its judgment . It maintained its decision as regards the hearing of NORP , considering that the fact that NORP was apparently not suffering from psychiatric problems and did not appear traumatised in her psycho - sexual development did not alter the conclusions reached by the therapists treating her who had advised against a second interview . It further considered that , on the whole , sufficient compensation had been provided for the fact that NORP had not been heard again and that the defence had not been given the opportunity of putting questions to her . This compensation consisted in particular of the studio interview conducted with NORP by a specialised police sergeant – which interview had been found to be of good quality by the experts L , PERSON , C. and PERSON and the video - tape of which had been put at the disposal of the defence as well as the experts and had been partially played back in court DATE ; the reports drawn up by the experts C. , L. and PERSON , PERSON and the CARDINAL therapists treating NORP ; and the appearance at hearings before ORG of the experts L , PERSON and PERSON According to ORG , the present case could be distinguished from those of P.S v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , DATE ) and PERSON v. the GPE ( no . CARDINAL , DATE ) , because in those cases the interviews with witnesses whom the defence was not able to question had not been videotaped . Conversely , it appeared from ORG v. GPE , ( no . CARDINAL , in particular LAW , ORG PERSON ) that the existence and the viewing of a videotape of the interview of a minor might constitute important compensation enabling the defence to challenge the statements and the credibility of the witness . The developmental - psychological examination only having taken place in DATE and , as a result , the obtaining of ( uncoloured ) information having been rendered more difficult , did not detract from the fact that this examination had provided insight into NORP ’s development and thus information relevant for the assessment of the studio interview . ORG also took into account that the defence had only requested that NORP be heard again as from DATE .

CARDINAL . As to NORP ’s statement , ORG considered that it was sufficiently clear from NORP ’s mother ’s and grandmother ’s statements that NORP had not been pressured to denounce her father ; that she had told her mother about the events on DATE they took place ; and that it was unlikely that NORP had been mistaken about the events and the person in issue so few hours after they had taken place . It further considered that , even though an assessment of the statement based on the method of ORG could not give a decisive answer about the reliability of NORP ’s statement , it was , at least , likely that the statement had not been a deliberate lie ( bewust gelogen ) . In this regard , the court also attached weight to the clinical assessment by the experts PERSON and PERSON that it was highly unlikely that NORP ’s statements had been made up or that words had been put into her mouth . Consequently , and having itself viewed the videotape , ORG found PERSON ’s statement to be reliable .

CARDINAL . The Court of Appeal quashed the judgment of ORG , convicted the applicant of an attempt to perform acts with a child under DATE twelve , consisting of the sexual penetration of that child ’s body , and of sexual abuse of his minor child , and sentenced him to a partially suspended term of imprisonment of DATE . It based this conviction on NORP ’s statement made during the studio interview , the statement of the applicant that during DATE in question he had been alone with NORP and had lain next to her in bed , and the statement of NORP ’s mother and grandmother about what NORP had told them after DATE and the way in which NORP had told it .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal on points of law ( cassatie ) alleging a breach of LAW in that he had not been afforded an opportunity to put questions to NORP He also complained that his conviction had wrongly been based on the statement of NORP , while sufficient supporting evidence was lacking .

CARDINAL . By judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG rejected the appeal on points of law . As regards the complaint that the applicant ’s request to examine NORP as a witness had been refused , ORG noted that pursuant to article FAC § CARDINAL sub ( b ) of MONEY Procedure ( PERSON ) , a court may decide not to proceed to the hearing of a witness if there are serious reasons for presuming that the making of a statement at a hearing of the court would be harmful to the health and well - being of the witness and if the prevention of that harm outweighed the importance of the possibility to have the witness examined at the hearing . ORG continued as follows :

CARDINAL.CARDINAL.CARDINAL . ORG has not negated the above ... In its considerations about the evidence it has set out the reasons why it found that compensation enabling an effective defence was provided for the inability to examine the victim as a witness . Seen also against the background of that finding ... the rejection of the request [ to examine the victim as a witness ] has been sufficiently reasoned .

CARDINAL . ORG has based that rejection on its opinion that there were serious reasons for assuming that another interview could be harmful to the health and well - being of the victim . In reaching that opinion ORG based itself on the views of the experts treating the victim . ORG further considered that the contents of the subsequent report of the [ developmental - psychological examination ] did not lead to a different conclusion , but that , on the contrary , it supported the views of the abovementioned experts . ”

CARDINAL . ORG rejected the complaint about the use of R. ’s statement in evidence , considering that that complaint overlooked the finding of ORG – which finding had not been disputed in the appeal on points of law and had been confirmed by ORG – that sufficient compensation had been provided for the lack of opportunity to examine the witness .

CARDINAL . Finally , ORG found ex proprio motu that the proceedings before it had exceeded the reasonable time requirement and for that reason it quashed the judgment of ORG in so far as the imposed sentence was concerned . It sentenced the applicant to a partially suspended prison term of DATE .
